titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

p.hi: The snow had not wholly disappeared, and its survival had been assisted by a frost. I asked the gardener whether the fruit prospects were endangered. He thought nothing was sufficiently advanced to take any damage.

came to go through the letters, and then I made my dispositions for departure. We left the palace in two cabs. Ella & Mary Webbe in one, and I with Harold & Ernest in the other. We travelled as far as Oxford together. There Mary & Ernest got out.
joined us at Worcester. He had been week–ending with

at Madresfield. We were distressed at his frail & aged appearance. There were no porters at Paddington, but we did succeed in getting a taxi after some delay, & were driven to Garland's Hotel. I walked round to the Athenaeum, where I fell in with Sir Richard Harrington & Radcliffe. I took up the "
" & read a review of the volume in which my King's College Lecture appears. It is hostile but less virulent than I had thought probable.
disclaiming any connexion with the "Challenge", which seems to have definitely committed itself to Disestablishment.
